text: CCDM 32.2.3, Drafting Published Guidance, is being revised to reflect current office practice.
References were updated. The exhibits were made compliant with the requirements of Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act.
This section supersedes CCDM 32.2.3 dated December 22, 2009.

Guidance
) This section provides basic information concerning the components and for- matting requirements of a publication and on how to research and develop a publication. (
) Macros can assist in drafting publication items. The drafting attorney should use the
ord Macros under the CC Macros heading on the Menu toolbar Microsoft Word to begin drafting revenue rulings, revenue procedures, and announcements. (

) When a drafting attorney begins the research process for a proposed tion item, the drafting attorney should begin by reading the relevant checking internal sources for previously addressed publication items, and doing a comprehensive electronic database search. (

) If a proposed publication is based on a letter ruling or technical advice, the drafting attorney should read all of the authorities cited in the ruling or technical advice to become familiar with the authorities to make sure they on point and that they stand for the propositions cited. (
) The drafting attorney should make certain that all citations are accurate and current and check court cases in a citator to make certain that the case is good authority. (
) The Bulletin Index-Digest System (BIDS), which is current through

, is historic source for the drafting attorney to check to make certain that the has not been published. The BIDS consists of digests of revenue rulings, revenue procedures, certain court opinions, notices, and other miscellaneous items giving citations to the full documents, and contains extensive finding and summaries arranged by subject matter. See Exhibit
, Item B. (

) The drafting attorney should also conduct a general search in an electronic database for any publications, including publications that are not in the same series, that may have modified the Service’s position on the subject matter the proposed publication. Since publications that are not in the same series may have modified the Service’s position on the issue, the drafting attorney should not rely solely on Shepard’s Citations. (

) Additional research. If appropriate, the drafting attorney should read treatises and articles in the area involved and consult informally with experts. The drafting attorney should conduct any other research needed in the analysis the matter. (
) The proposed publication is typed by using the
ord Macros in Microsoft Word. Exhibits
through
illustrate the formats for revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, announcements, and news releases. (
) The left and right margins are always
inch, the bottom margin of the first
page is not less than
inches, and the top margin is
inch from the top of
the page. (

) In the body of all proposed publications, the first line of each main paragraph is indented five spaces. All material in the body of a proposed publication is typed double spaced except for long quotations and certain other indented material. (
) Chief Counsel Directives Manual

When a drafting attorney begins the research process for a proposed publica- tion item, the drafting attorney should begin by reading the relevant authorities, checking internal sources for previously addressed publication items, and doing a comprehensive electronic database search.
32.2.3.3 (10-28-2011) General Formatting Guidelines
Chief Counsel Publication (

) Although not required for publication in the IRB, the drafting attorney should include page numbering in proposed publication items. This will assist reviewers in keeping track of publications submitted for review. As there is IRB requirement for page numbering, there is no specified format for page numbering. (
) The formats for typical revenue rulings under the Internal Revenue Code under tax conventions are set forth in Exhibit
and Exhibit
, respectively. The formats for a typical revenue procedure, notice, announce- ment, and news release are set forth in Exhibits
through

) Manuscript of publications for the IRB must conform to the procedures set in this Handbook and be error free. Assigned reviewers must ensure that the hard copies and electronic copy forwarded for publication are exactly the same. The Bulletin Unit is authorized to return any manuscript to the drafting attorney for correction if the material does not meet the standards of accept- ability for submission to the printer. (
) Each proposed publication is identified by its CASE-MIS number in the right corner of the first page (one inch from the top of the page) on the same line as the draft date. (
) The date of the latest changes made to the proposed publication (for Draft Date:

) must be typed on the first page of each proposed tion in the upper left corner on the line opposite the control number, one inch from the top of the page. This date reflects changes made to any page since the last dated draft. This draft date appears only on the first page of the proposed publication. See Exhibits
through

) Revenue rulings and revenue procedures are printed within an identification system of IRB “Parts” and coding references for purposes of indexing them — the IRB. Announcements and notices are printed within an identification of IRB “Parts” but with no coding references. News releases are not printed the IRB. The text of a revenue ruling or revenue procedure is published at place indicated by its primary coding, and a cross-reference is included at every point indicated by a secondary coding. The drafting attorney of the proposed publication has responsibility for assigning the correct Part in accordance with the outline shown in the Introduction printed in each IRB. See Exhibit
The current placement of publications and cross- references in these Parts is discussed below. (
) Part I of the IRB includes revenue rulings, Supreme Court opinions and Treasury Decisions based on the provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of

) Part II of the IRB includes revenue rulings that state a Service position tax convention and related Treasury Decision, cross-references for revenue rulings and revenue procedures, as appropriate, and legislation and related committee reports. (
) Part III of the IRB includes revenue procedures, notices, and other miscella- neous material. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
G

Although not required for publication in the IRB, the drafting attorney should include page numbering in proposed publication items. This will assist reviewers in keeping track of publications submitted for review. As there is IRB requirement for page numbering, there is no specified format for page numbering. The formats for typical revenue rulings under the Internal Revenue Code under tax conventions are set forth in Exhibit

Manuscript of publications for the IRB must conform to the procedures set in this Handbook and be error free. Assigned reviewers must ensure that hard copies and electronic copy forwarded for publication are exactly the same. The Bulletin Unit is authorized to return any manuscript to the attorney for correction if the material does not meet the standards of ability for submission to the printer.

Part II of the IRB includes revenue rulings that state a Service position under a tax convention and related Treasury Decision, cross-references for revenue rulings and revenue procedures, as appropriate, and legislation and related committee reports.
) Part IV of the IRB includes notices of proposed rulemaking, disbarment and suspension lists, and announcements. (

) The Part of the IRB in which the publication will appear is typed two lines below the CASE-MIS number beginning at the left margin for revenue rulings and revenue procedures and four lines below the control number for notices and announcements. “Part” is typed with the initial letter capitalized . The number is designated by a roman numeral. See Exhibits
through

) The Internal Revenue Code and the regulations under which each — General ruling is published (cid:
) The tax convention and related Treasury Decision under which each revenue ruling is published (cid:
) The Statement of Procedural Rules under which each revenue procedure published (

) The attorney drafting the proposed publication is responsible for selecting the correct primary and secondary coding and for preparing a Cross-Reference Sheet for each secondary coding provision. See CCDM
) References to both the Code and the regulations, whether in the primary or secondary coding, should include only the Code or regulation section Correct:
Incorrect:
The term “coding” refers to the identification of the provisions of:
References to both the Code and the regulations, whether in the primary or the secondary coding, should include only the Code or regulation section number.
Temporary regulations may be used in coding if final regulations have not been adopted.
Example: Rev. Rul. 78-193, 1978-1 C.B. 12

(5) Proposed regulations are never used in coding. If neither final nor temporary regulations have been issued, or if the regulations do not reflect recent legisla- tion that is the subject of the proposed publication, the regulations reference is omitted.
Example: Rev. Ruls. 78-191 and 78-192, 1978-1 C.B. 8

) Preceding the text of each revenue ruling certain identification, referred to as primary coding, must be shown. This includes either the number and title of the Code and regulations (including temporary regulations) sections principally involved in the revenue ruling or the name of the tax convention principally involved and a citation to the tax convention. (
) Preceding the text of each revenue procedure the section number and title of the Statement of Procedural Rules under which the revenue procedure is

This entry is typed the initial letter of each principal word capitalized (no period at the end of title) and with the section number separated from the title by a period and hyphens (without spaces). This entry is typed across the page to the right margin; if a second line is required, it is typed beginning at the left margin. Exhibit

In practically all cases, only the first word in regulations title begins with a capital letter. This entry is typed across the to the right margin; if a second line is required, it is typed beginning at the margin. Citations to any cross-reference needed are shown in the secondary line. The secondary coding entry generally begins with an opening followed by “Also Section(s)” followed in order by the numbers of all sections cross-referenced, semicolon, and the numbers of the pertinent sections of the related regulations, followed by a closing parenthesis, ending with a period. All of the secondary coding information is typed, in parentheses, the left margin on the first line below the line beginning “
CFR.” If “
is not typed in the primary coding entry because there are no under the primary Code section, the cross-reference citation is typed lines below the primary Code section number with “

CFR” typed the cross-reference regulations section designation. The secondary coding entry is typed across the page to the right second line is required, it is typed beginning at the left margin. All of the secondary coding information is typed, in parentheses, the left margin on the first line below the citation to the tax convention. Chief Counsel Publication (

) Citations to cross-references needed under any other provision of the Statement of Procedural Rules are shown in a separate secondary coding that begins with “Also Section,” is enclosed in parentheses, and is typed at left margin on the first line below the line that begins “

CFR.” Citations to cross-references needed under any provision of the Code are shown on a separate secondary coding line, which begins with an opening parenthesis followed by “Also Part I, Section(s),” followed by the numbers of all Code sections cross-referenced, semi-colon, and the numbers of the pertinent sections of the related regulations, followed by a closing parenthesis, with a period. (

) This secondary coding line is also enclosed in parentheses and is typed at left margin on the first line below any secondary coding to the Statement of Procedural Rules or, if there is none, on the first line below the line that “
CFR.” (
) The secondary coding entry is typed across the page to the right margin; if second line is required, it is typed beginning at the left margin. (
) A blank space of

lines following the primary and secondary coding is left the revenue ruling or revenue procedure to allow the Bulletin Unit to insert Number and highlight. No space is needed for a notice, announcement, or news release. (

) The abbreviation “Rev. Rul.” or “Rev. Proc.” is typed following the blank and starting at the left margin. The words “notice”, “announcement,” and release” are not abbreviated and are prepared pursuant to Exhibit
, Exhibit
, and Exhibit
, respectively. (

) Headings identifying the various parts of a revenue ruling or revenue procedure are typed in all upper case letters. The first heading is typed lines below “Rev. Rul.” or “Rev. Proc.” For revenue rulings, the headings typed flush with the left margin and are not followed by a period. For procedures, the headings are assigned section numbers and are typed with the margin. The word “SECTION” is typed using all capital letters. Headings are not always needed in notices and announcements, and are not used in news releases. If headings are used, follow the guidelines provided for revenue rulings or revenue procedures above. (
) A Cross-Reference Sheet is prepared for each secondary coding reference insertion in the proper place in the IRB. (

) The Cross-Reference Sheets carry secondary coding and use as their coding those sections of the Code and regulations (or tax conventions and related Treasury Decisions or Statement of Procedural Rules) shown in the secondary coding of the revenue ruling or revenue procedure. (

) The Cross-Reference Sheet does not state a holding. It is usually cast in form of a question. This statement ends with appropriate final punctuation is followed by the words, “See Rev. Rul. page .” or “See Rev. Proc. , page .” (

) When the project is being forwarded for publication, a separate Cross- Reference Sheet is prepared for each cross-referenced section of the of a tax convention, or of the Statement of Procedural Rules, in accordance with the format illustrated in Exhibit

Published Guidance
) The body of a revenue ruling or revenue procedure generally is organized certain components. Headings are usually used for each component of of Revenue publications. Notices, and (
) Revenue rulings are current authority and should be written in the present tense. For example: “Rev. Rul.
I.R.B.
, holds ... .” speak from the perspective of the Service. Thus, revenue rulings should contain language such as “The IRS today announced ”—this language from the perspective of a newspaper. (

) Most revenue rulings interpret the law with respect to a particular set of They should be written so that the principles covered are clearly of Revenue Revenue rulings that interpret tax conventions are unique to the office of Associate Chief Counsel (International). Most of the components of each of revenue ruling are the same. (

) The body of a revenue ruling may include some or all of the following nents: issue, facts, law, analysis, holding, effect on other revenue rulings documents), prospective application, and drafting information. See Exhibit
for the format of a proposed revenue ruling under the Internal Revenue Code and Exhibit
for the format of a proposed revenue ruling under a Tax Convention. (
) Headings are used to identify the following components, as needed. They presented in uppercase letters and are typically in the following order: (cid:
) ISSUE(S) (cid:
) FACTS (cid:
) LAW (cid:
) ANALYSIS (cid:
) HOLDING(S) (cid:
) EFFECT ON OTHER REVENUE RULINGS (or DOCUMENTS) (cid:
) PROSPECTIVE APPLICATION (cid:
) DRAFTING INFORMATION (
) Two headings may be combined when appropriate. Example: ISSUE AND FACTS; LAW AND ANALYSIS (
) If a particular revenue ruling does not lend itself to this format, the may be omitted altogether. For an example see Rev. Rul.

) The issue is the question to be answered by the revenue ruling. The issue should be drafted with the holding of the revenue ruling clearly in mind because the holding must be directly responsive to, and ordinarily must the language of, the issue. The issue should be stated in ordinary question format. (
) Chief Counsel Directives Manual
Headings are used to identify the following components, as needed. They are presented in uppercase letters and are typically in the following order:
If a particular revenue ruling does not lend itself to this format, the headings may be omitted altogether. For an example see Rev. Rul. 2001-1, 2001-1 C.B.

The issue is the question to be answered by the revenue ruling. The issue should be drafted with the holding of the revenue ruling clearly in mind because the holding must be directly responsive to, and ordinarily must parallel the language of, the issue. The issue should be stated in ordinary question format.
32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook
Example 1: Is the Irish wealth tax deductible under section 164 ... ?
Example 2: Does a leasehold interest qualify under section 1033(f) ...
Example
: If the income of X corporation is diverted to Y corporation, is that income ... ? (
) If more than one issue is discussed in a revenue ruling, the issues should be numbered for easy reference. See Exhibit

) Clearly state the specific facts on which the holding is based. Include all that are relevant to a proper understanding of the holding. Do not introduce fact for the first time in another section of the revenue ruling. (
) Eliminate extraneous facts because their presence in a revenue ruling may cloud the message of the holding. (
) Present two or more factual situations in the same revenue ruling as
... .” and “Situation
... .” or in some similar manner. See Exhibit (
) Tailor the facts, particularly the dates, to fit the period to which a particular statutory provision applies. (

) Words of limitation in the fact statement may help narrow the focus of a of the revenue ruling to the precise issue being addressed. For example, a sentence such as “Apart from the lack of a private foundation, the plan satisfies the guidelines of Rev. Proc.
C.B.

,” helps the understand what is and is not being decided in the revenue ruling. Similarly, sentence could be included after relevant facts are described such as, for the question at issue, the transaction meets the requirements of section of the Code.” (

) The LAW section includes discussions of relevant provisions of the Internal Revenue Code, regulations, court opinions, and other authorities, including other publication items. (

) The most directly applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code and regulations are paraphrased. If, however, the holding rests upon specific language in the Internal Revenue Code or regulations, that language may be quoted. When quoting or paraphrasing a section of the Internal Revenue or regulations, it is sufficient to say that the section “provides” rather than it “provides, in part, ... ,” unless the material presented would be misleading Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. Guidance
without an affirmative statement that only part of the Internal Revenue Code regulations was quoted or paraphrased. (

) A relevant court opinion that bears directly upon an issue addressed in the revenue ruling may be used in the LAW or LAW AND ANALYSIS section some indication of what the opinion means. When specific language of a opinion is quoted or paraphrased, it is correct to say that the court “stated.” (

) A court opinion that is adverse to the Service position will not be cited as authority in revenue rulings if the Service has decided not to follow that either by a published nonacquiescence (in Tax Court cases) or by an unpub- lished Action on Decision (in other federal court cases). Opinions of the Supreme Court of the United States, however, are always followed. it is not advisable to cite an adverse opinion in which the Commissioner has acquiesced in result only. An adverse opinion may, however, be cited in to distinguish it from the facts stated in or the law applicable to the present revenue ruling, or when a revenue ruling is being used to announce that the Service will follow an adverse opinion in a particular case. An opinion that supports the Service’s position in a matter may nevertheless be for use in a revenue ruling if it would adversely affect another Service (

) An unreported opinion of any court, including a memorandum opinion of the Tax Court or the Board of Tax Appeals, is cited only if better authority is not available. When an unreported opinion is used in a revenue ruling, it is not cited to an unofficial private commercial reporter. (

) Other publication items that bear directly upon the issue may be used in the LAW or LAW AND ANALYSIS section with some indication of what they When the holding of an existing ruling is referred to in a new revenue ruling, is correct to refer to that holding in the present tense because it is current authority. THUS: “Rev. Rul.
C.B.
, holds ... .” (
) Relevant federal tax statutes other than the Internal Revenue Code may be cited, paraphrased, or quoted, as appropriate. (

) Congressional material should be used with care. Committee reports may be cited, paraphrased, or quoted. A Joint Committee General Explanation of a revenue act (commonly referred to as the “Bluebook”), however, should not cited as authority. These explanations reflect only the views of the staff of Joint Committee as to the intent of Congress and are not part of the history of the act. Extracts from congressional debate or hearings generally used only if better authority is not available and only if the speaker had cant official authority, such as chairperson of a committee. (
) Treatises (such as Fletcher on Corporations or Scott on Trusts) may be cited on a selective basis only when better authority is not available. (
) Articles in professional journals and legal encyclopedias, editorial comments commercial tax services, and similar items should not be cited.
without an affirmative statement that only part of the Internal Revenue Code or regulations was quoted or paraphrased.

Other publication items that bear directly upon the issue may be used in the LAW or LAW AND ANALYSIS section with some indication of what they mean. When the holding of an existing ruling is referred to in a new revenue ruling, it is correct to refer to that holding in the present tense because it is current authority. THUS: “Rev. Rul. 92-69, 1992-2 C.B. 51, holds ... .”
Treatises (such as Fletcher on Corporations or Scott on Trusts) may be cited on a selective basis only when better authority is not available.
Articles in professional journals and legal encyclopedias, editorial comments in commercial tax services, and similar items should not be cited.
32.2 Chief Counsel Publication Handbook
Chief Counsel Publication (

) The analysis is the explanation of how the cited authorities apply to the issue(s) and facts presented in order to reach the conclusion(s) of the ruling. Because a revenue ruling serves as research material for taxpayers Service personnel, it should contain sufficient analysis to permit some of analogy in similar factual situations. Only in rare situations may the of the Service be stated without analysis or explanation. (
) When more than one issue or situation is presented, the analysis of each be presented separately, if desired, under headings such as “Analysis – (
)” or “Analysis – Situation

) The holding must be directly responsive to, and ordinarily must parallel the language of, the issue. It should be stated clearly and definitively. Normally, is stated without introductory words, such as “Accordingly.” (

) The holding should not be drafted with reference to the particular taxpayer identified in the facts. For example, the holding should not state, “Under the facts of this ruling, X may deduct advertising expenditures as an ordinary necessary business expense under section
) If more than one issue or more than one factual situation is discussed in revenue ruling, the holdings should be clearly labeled to show which issue relates to which holding. (

) If another revenue ruling (or another document) is affected (that is, clarified, distinguished, modified, obsoleted, revoked, superseded, supple- on Other Revenue mented, or suspended, as those terms are described in CCDM

, (or Documents) of Terms) by the new revenue ruling, that fact must be stated. The extent of the change should be described precisely; it is not sufficient to state that a prior revenue ruling is modified “to the extent that it is inconsistent (

) Generally, it is helpful to discuss the effect on another publication and the extent of the change in the ANALYSIS or LAW AND ANALYSIS section of new revenue ruling. Nevertheless, the EFFECT ON OTHER REVENUE RULINGS (or DOCUMENTS) heading must be retained and be followed by statement that “Rev. Rul. xx-xxx is how affected.” This statement in the EFFECT ON OTHER REVENUE RULINGS (or DOCUMENTS) section is necessary both to ensure clarity and to aid in updating finding lists and citators. (

) When significant changes are made by a new revenue ruling to a prior revenue ruling, it is usually desirable to incorporate into the new revenue the remaining current provisions of the previous revenue ruling so that the previous ruling may be modified and superseded. (

) A new revenue ruling may affect a prior publication in more than one way. example, the new revenue ruling may amplify and supersede, clarify and supersede, or modify and supersede the prior publication. In these cases, relevant terms are used in the EFFECT ON OTHER REVENUE RULINGS DOCUMENTS) section. (Illustration: “Rev. Rul. xx–xxx is amplified and seded.”)

) Revenue rulings apply retroactively unless they include a specific statement indicating, under the authority of section
), the extent to which are to be applied without retroactive effect (that is, prospectively). If a taken in a revenue ruling is to be applied only prospectively it must be clearly and section

) Section

) provides the Secretary with the authority to prescribe extent to which any ruling is to be applied prospectively only. This authority been redelegated to the Deputy Associate Chief Counsel level. The this authority requires an affirmative action. Approval by an Associate or Deputy Associate Chief Counsel of a revenue ruling containing a clear statement that a position taken in the ruling is to be applied only is sufficient. (
) Revocation or modification of a previous revenue ruling is usually made retroactive to the extent that the new revenue ruling has adverse tax consequences to taxpayers. (

) DRAFTING INFORMATION A numbering system is used in combination with the headings in revenue pro- cedures. The word “SECTION” is typed in capital letters beginning at the left margin for the heading of the first section, followed in order by a space, the figure

, a period, a space and the heading typed in capitals (no period at the end of the heading). The word “SECTION” is used for all subsequent sections (and in the table of contents, if applicable). If a section contains more than paragraph, it may be divided further into subsections, paragraphs, subpara- graphs, Divisions, and subdivisions, which are assigned numerical or alphabetical designations (and may be assigned subheadings), as illustrated Exhibit
The subsection designation is indented five spaces from the margin, and each successive division is indented three spaces further, as shown below:
(Left margin) SECTION 1, 2, 3, etc.; .01, .02, etc. (subsections); (1), (2), etc. (paragraphs); (a), (b), etc. (subparagraphs); (i), (ii), etc. (divisions); and (A), (B), etc. (subdivisions).

Example: Rev. Proc.
C.B.
) The purpose of the revenue procedure should be clearly and directly For example, “This revenue procedure provides ... . ” (

) When a revenue procedure changes a prior revenue procedure, a clear nation of the significant change(s) must be stated in the CHANGES section the new revenue procedure. Reference should be made to each affected section of the earlier revenue procedure describing each significant change and the reason for it. (

) The BACKGROUND section explains the need for the revenue procedure. addition, a discussion of the relevant Internal Revenue Code sections, tions, and prior revenue procedures and revenue rulings that helped form a basis for the revenue procedure should be included in the BACKGROUND section. (
) The SCOPE section sets forth the extent of the application of the revenue procedure. If the revenue procedure does not apply to a particular situation SCOPE section should so state. (

) The PROCEDURE (OR APPLICATION) section sets forth in concise the various steps or requirements that are necessary to accomplish the (or purpose of the revenue procedure. It may be advantageous to use more one section with appropriate subheadings that describe the different covered by the revenue procedure. (
) The same rules apply to revenue procedures as to revenue rulings. (

) If another publication is affected (that is, amplified, clarified, distinguished, on Other Revenue modified, obsoleted, revoked, superseded, supplemented, or suspended, (or those terms are described in CCDM

, Use of Terms) by the new revenue procedure, that fact must be stated. The extent of the change be stated precisely; it is not sufficient to state that a prior revenue modified “to the extent that it is inconsistent herewith.” (

) If the effect on a prior publication is described in another section of the revenue procedure (for example, when a prior revenue procedure is super- seded and the significant changes are described in the CHANGES section the new revenue procedure), a statement that “Rev. Proc. xx-xxx is super- seded” must also be included in the EFFECT ON OTHER REVENUE PROCEDURES (or DOCUMENTS) section of the new procedure. This statement in the EFFECT ON OTHER REVENUE PROCEDURES (or DOCUMENTS) section is necessary both to ensure clarity and to aid in updating finding lists and citators. (

) A revenue procedure may affect a prior publication in more than one way. example, it may amplify and supersede, clarify and supersede, or modify supersede, etc. (In such cases both terms are used in the EFFECT ON OTHER REVENUE PROCEDURES (or DOCUMENTS) section. “Rev. Proc. xx-xxx is modified and superseded.”)

The purpose of the revenue procedure should be clearly and directly stated. For example, “This revenue procedure provides ... . ”
Chief Counsel Publication (
) Revenue procedures usually contain an EFFECTIVE DATE heading and provision. (

) Ordinarily, the effective date of a revenue procedure is either the date of cation or a later date when appropriate. In some cases, however, it is appropriate to state the effective date of a revenue procedure in other including in terms of periods beginning before publication of the revenue procedure, events occurring after the beginning of the year in which a procedure is published, or requests submitted after the beginning of the calendar year in which a revenue procedure is published. See Exhibit for sample effective date provisions. (

) When the effective date is intended to be concurrent with publication, the effective date should be the date of the IRB in which the revenue procedure published, or if the revenue procedure is released to the tax services in advance of its publication in the IRB, the effective date should be the date the release. See Exhibit
Do not state that the revenue procedure effective “immediately.” (
) Prospective application of revenue procedures does not require coding and cross-referencing to section

) The Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) requires federal agencies to obtain approval before any collection of information may be enforced. The Reduction Act potentially applies to revenue rulings, revenue procedures, notices, and announcements. (

) In general, the term “collection of information” means a reporting, ing, or disclosure requirement that is imposed on ten or more persons. It not matter whether the requirement is voluntary or mandatory or if the ment is imposed by statute. See
C.F.R. §

) The term “reporting requirement” means a requirement that persons provide information to an entity of the Federal government. For example, a that requires a separate statement to be attached to a tax return imposes a paperwork burden subject to the PRA. However, a publication that requires form to be filed does not impose a paperwork requirement subject to the because the form, and not the publication, is the “instrument of collection” is subject to the PRA. (

) The term “recordkeeping requirement” means that persons must maintain specified records, whether or not an entity of the federal government or any other person actually seeks access to the records or is provided such See
C.F.R. §
(m). (This mandate to maintain specified records is a requirement in addition to the general books and records requirement of section

) Thus, because a recordkeeping requirement is one that specified records, a publication that does not require that particular records maintained, but nonetheless prompts some taxpayer to maintain records sistent with the provisions of section
, does not impose a requirement. (
) The term “disclosure requirement” means that a person must disclose tion to third parties, the Federal government, or to the public at large. (
) See Exhibit
and Exhibit
for model language to use in proposed publications concerning the Paperwork Reduction Act. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.

Unlike other publications, news releases speak from the perspective of a third party. News releases are used to: (cid:
) Announce hearings (cid:
) Solicit comments (cid:
) Inform the public of a change in procedures (cid:

) Inform the public of a change in address News releases are nontechnical publications targeted at the nonpractitioner taxpayer public. Technical discussions must be kept to a minimum and such as Internal Revenue Code section numbers should be avoided if and, when used, relegated to the end of the release. Exhibit 32.2.3-1 (08-11-2004) Explanation of the Parts of the Internal Revenue Bulletin
A. The Bulletin is divided into four parts as follows:
This part includes rulings and decisions based on provisions of the Internal Revenue Code of
Part II.- Treaties and Tax Legislation
Part Ill.- Administrative, Procedural, and Miscellaneous

To the extent practicable, pertinent cross references to these subjects are contained in the other Parts and Subparts. Also included in this part are Bankruptcy Secrecy Act Administrative Rulings, which are issued by the department of the Treasury’s Office of the Assistant Secretary (Enforcement).
This part includes notices of proposed rulemaking, disbarment and suspension lists, and announcements.

The first Bulletin for each month includes a cumulative index for the matters published during the preceding months. These monthly indexes are cumulated on a semi-annual basis, and are published in the first Bulletin of the succeeding semiannual period respectively.

B. The Bulletin Index-Digest System (BIDS), a research and reference service supplementing the Bulletin, consists of four services: Service No. 1, Income Tax; Service No. 2, Estate and Gift Tax; Service No. 3, ment Taxes; and Service No. 4, Excise Taxes. Each service consists of a basic volume and a cumulative supplement that provides (1) finding lists of items published in the Bulletin, (2) digests of revenue rulings, revenue procedures, and other published items, and (3) indexes of Public Laws, Treasury Decisions, and tax Conventions.

Caution: Although the BIDS is an excellent starting point for researching historical publications, it is no longer published by the IRS. Therefore, publications and the referenced materials since approximately 1994 will not be included.

A. Revenue Rulings
1. With respect to a tax convention (from Rev. Rul. 2002-16, 2002-15 l.R.B. 740):

This revenue ruling is effective with respect to taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2001. This revenue ruling will cease to be effective if the Netherlands Indi- vidual Income Tax Act of 2001 is modified in any material respect for tax years that are affected by such change. Taxpayers are responsible for determining whether any such modifications have occurred.
3. From a date certain with exceptions (from Rev. Rul. 2002-55, 2002-37 I.R.B. 1):
This revenue ruling is effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. However, taxpayers may rely on this revenue ruling for prior periods.
4. From a specified event (from Rev. Rul. 2002-35, 2002-23 I.R.B. 1067):
This revenue ruling is effective for payments to employees after October 13,1988 (the date of enactment for § 62(c), as part of the Family Support Act of 1988).
5. With prospective application (from Rev. Rul. 99-40, 1999-2 C.B. 441):

Pursuant to § 7805(b), this ruling will not be applied adversely to a taxpayer that desig- nated an overpayment to apply to an installment of estimated tax in accordance with Rev. Rul. 84-58 prior to October 4, 1999.
1. Stated in terms of a specific date (from Rev. Proc. 98-39, 1998-1 C.B.
This revenue procedure is effective on August 18, 1997.

5. Until a date specified in future guidance (from Rev. Proc. 2002-12, 2001-3 I.R.B. 335):

of this revenue procedure), and the application or ruling request is pending with the national office on December

1. For events occurring after a certain date (from Notice 2000-38, 2000-2 C.B. 174):

This notice is applicable with respect to deferrals and distributions made after December 31, 2001. Plan sponsors, plan administrators, and taxpayers may rely on this notice for distributions and deferrals before January 1, 2002.

3. To apply to certain elections (from Notice 98-25, 1998-1 C.B. 979):

This notice applies to an election made for the first taxable year of a trust beginning after December 31, 1996. The provisions of this notice will be incorporated into regula- tions that will be effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1996.
4. To alert taxpayers to the effect of a new regulations on existing revenue rulings and revenue procedures (from Notice 97-1, 1997-1 C.B. 348):

... effective January 1, 1997, such revenue rulings and revenue procedures are obsolete to the extent that they use the prior classification regulations to differentiate between partnerships and associations.

1 — For a revenue procedure for which approval is sought under 44 U.S.C. 3507(c) [to be used when the revenue procedure is issued in proposed form]

The collection[s] of information contained in this revenue procedure will be submitted to the Office of Management and Budget for review in accordance with the Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. 3507(c)).
An agency may not conduct or sponsor, and a person is not required to respond to, a collection of infor- unless the collection of information displays a valid OMB control number.

This information will be to [brief description of how the collected information will be used]. The collection[s] of information [voluntary/required to obtain a benefit/mandatory] . The likely respondents are [use one or more following: individuals, state or local governments, farms, business or other for-profit institutions, institutions, and small businesses or organizations] .

The estimated annual burden per respondent/recordkeeper varies from [enter hours] to [enter hours], depending on individual circumstances, with an estimated average of [enter hours]. The estimated number of respondents and/or recordkeepers is [enter number].
The estimated annual frequency of responses (used for reporting requirements only) is [enter frequency] .

Books or records relating to a collection of information must be retained as long as their contents may become material in the administration of any internal revenue law. Generally, tax returns and tax return informa- tion are confidential, as required by 26 U.S.C. 6103.
